action.primary: Promotes the movement of Qi, awakens the Spleen and eases the Middle

indications: Qi Stagnation in the Liver, Spleen and Stomach leading to epigastric distention and pain

action.primary: Dredges and regulates Liver Qi and stops pain

indications: Chest and flank distention and pain from Liver Qi Stagnation

action.primary: Descends and drains to reduce Phlegm and stop cough

indications: Cough with profuse sputum and a stifling sensation in the chest

contraindications: Use care with those who are Yin Deficient.
Use care with those who have Blood Dryness.

useCases: Epigastric and abdominal pain with belching.
Chest and flank distention and pain from Liver Qi Stagnation.
Coughing with profuse sputum and a stifling sensation in the chest.
A bitter taste in the mouth.

notes: This herb treats "waist and leg Qi".
This herb is relatively mild and needs to be combined with other herbs for maximum effectiveness.

Both Xiang Yuan and Fr. Citri Sarcodactylis #{FoShou} Fo Shou are warm and of similar nature. Xiang Yuan specifically regulates Lung and Spleen Qi and breaks up Phlegm and pathogenic water to treat cough due to clogged Qi. It is best to remove the pith and kernels to prevent excess astringency due to their sour tastes. Fo Shou enters the Stomach and breaks up Qi Stagnation to treat nausea, vomiting and dysenteric disorders with tenesmus.
Dry-fried Citron Chao Xiang Yuan or Zhi Xiang Yuan has a more moderate acrid, dispersing action and is less drying.
Pericarpium Citri Xiang Yuan Pi has a stronger Qi circulating function.
